unnormalised: So, someone asked me about my experience with the CBSE grading system back in the day. Well, here's the story. I finished my Class 10th from Ryan International School, Delhi, in 2008. Back then, CGPA wasn't a thing; we were graded on percentage marks. I remember aiming for 90%+ throughout the year, driven by the pressure of joining the science stream in Class 11th. My parents, especially my mom, were quite particular about academics.
normalised: So, someone asked me about my experience with the C-B-S-E grading system back in the day. Well, here's the story. I finished my Class tenth from Ryan International School, Delhi, in two thousand eight. Back then, C-G-P-A wasn't a thing; we were graded on percentage marks. I remember aiming for ninety percent plus throughout the year, driven by the pressure of joining the science stream in Class eleventh. My parents, especially my mom, were quite particular about academics.

unnormalised: The results came out in May, and I scored 88.4%. Initially, I was a bit disappointed. I mean, 88.4% is a good score, right? But I had set such high expectations that anything below 90% felt like a letdown. My best subjects were Maths and Science, where I scored 92 and 90 respectively. English, surprisingly, pulled me down a bit to 85. Social Studies was a comfortable 87. Hindi? Let's just say I scraped by with a 88.
normalised: The results came out in May, and I scored eighty eight point four percent. Initially, I was a bit disappointed. I mean, eighty eight point four percent is a good score, right? But I had set such high expectations that anything below ninety percent felt like a letdown. My best subjects were Maths and Science, where I scored ninety two and ninety respectively. English, surprisingly, pulled me down a bit to eighty five. Social Studies was a comfortable eighty seven. Hindi? Let's just say I scraped by with an eighty eight.

unnormalised: My friend, Rohan, who studied at DPS R.K. Puram, got 91.2%. There was this unspoken competition between us, and for a brief moment, I felt envious. But then I realised, 88.4% was still a solid score, and it was enough to secure a spot in the science stream with PCM (Physics, Chemistry, Maths) at my preferred school. A lot of students who scored less than 60%, which was considered a passing grade back then, opted for humanities or commerce.
normalised: My friend, Rohan, who studied at D-P-S R-K. Puram, got ninety one point two percent. There was this unspoken competition between us, and for a brief moment, I felt envious. But then I realised, eighty eight point four percent was still a solid score, and it was enough to secure a spot in the science stream with P-C-M (Physics, Chemistry, Maths) at my preferred school. A lot of students who scored less than sixty percent, which was considered a passing grade back then, opted for humanities or commerce.

unnormalised: The cut-offs for science were usually quite high. To get into the top schools for science, you needed at least 85%, if not higher. Some of the top schools in Delhi like Vasant Valley and Amity International even had cutoffs as high as 90% for science with computer science. Rohan ended up going to coaching classes costing him and his parents around Rs. 50,000 to study for IIT-JEE. I thought to myself, let me just focus on my school exams.
normalised: The cut-offs for science were usually quite high. To get into the top schools for science, you needed at least eighty five percent, if not higher. Some of the top schools in Delhi like Vasant Valley and Amity International even had cutoffs as high as ninety percent for science with computer science. Rohan ended up going to coaching classes costing him and his parents around rupee fifty thousand to study for I-I-T-J-E-E. I thought to myself, let me just focus on my school exams.

unnormalised: After Class 10th, the focus shifted from overall percentage to individual subject performance. Good marks in Class 12th were crucial for college admissions. The pressure was immense, especially with competitive exams like JEE and NEET looming large for students aiming for engineering and medical colleges respectively. People in my colony even started saying things like, “Beta, IIT nahi mila toh kya karoge?”
normalised: After Class tenth, the focus shifted from overall percentage to individual subject performance. Good marks in Class twelfth were crucial for college admissions. The pressure was immense, especially with competitive exams like J-E-E and N-E-E-T looming large for students aiming for engineering and medical colleges respectively. People in my colony even started saying things like, “Beta, I-I-T nahi mila toh kya karoge?”

unnormalised: Looking back, those days were quite stressful. But Class 10th marks are just one milestone in life. What matters more is what you do after that. I ended up doing my B.Tech from a decent engineering college, not an IIT, but still managed to get a good job. Ultimately, it's about continuous learning and growth, not just a number on a marksheet. Plus, if you ask me the CGPA system is too confusing. I prefer the good old percentage system.
